Micah: "This hasn't really been reported yet, but this specific dataset includes information about Roskomnadzor censoring DDoSecrets itself. title: People We Meet: Ronald, the homeless coder on Albion Street

last_post.content:
San Francisco’s techies and homeless residents seem like opposite poles of the city – but not for Ronald, a 26-year-old programmer living in a Honda Odyssey. He can be seen working at the desk he sets up next to his car on Albion Street between 16th and 17th. Sometimes he strings a tarp from his van to a nearby tree branch and sometimes his laptop is hooked up to the solar power he generates from the panels atop his car.

https://missionlocal.org/2023/04/people-we-meet-ronald-the-homeless-coder-on-albion-street/

#sanfrancisco #MissionSF
#Tech

title: 30B model now needs only 5.8GB of RAM? How? · ggerganov/llama.cpp · Discussion #638

last_post.content:
I honestly don't understand how it's possible for LLaMa's 30B parameters to be mmap'd from disk, then memory profiling reveals that only 1.6Gb of data of the 20Gb file need to be loaded to simulate?

There's nothing about LLaMa's architecture that's designed to be sparse...

title: Programmers, beware: ChatGPT has ruined your magic trick

last_post.content: I usually stop reading after his name appears. This is the usual thing: “I’m smarter than everyone else. Tech journalists are idiots who can’t see the future. (Please ignore the 1,000 times I was wrong and doubled down or pretended I never said those things.)” I don’t know any tech journalist who thinks it’s a “parlour trick.” I think it’s a *FAD* because it has very domains-specific utility and is being hyped as a general-purpose solution. https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2023/apr/01/chatgpt-write-code-computer-programmer-software

title: Judge Deals Fox Defeat In Dominion Case

last_post.content:
Judge Deals Fox Defeat In Dominion Case

Court found that 'none' of the statements Fox anchors made about Dominion's role in the 2020 election were true.

A Delaware judge allowed Dominion Voting Systems’ lawsuit against Fox News to proceed, striking down the conservative network’s claims while finding in favor partly for the aggrieved voting machine company.

Delaware Superior Court Judge Eric Davis ruled in favor of Dominion on one point: that public statements made by Fox employees about the voting machine company were completely false.

“The evidence developed in this civil proceeding demonstrates that [it] is CRYSTAL clear that none of the Statements relating to Dominion about the 2020 election are true,” Davis wrote.
https://talkingpointsmemo.com/news/judge-deals-fox-defeat-in-dominion-case

https://acrobat.adobe.com/link/review?uri=urn:aaid:scds:US:641bb440-903e-34fa-8705-df893ac1f43d

#melancholy #cooking #youtube #mexico #video #food #+

Possible reasons for post-exertional malaise (#PEM) in people with #LongCOVID and/or #MECFS

Muscle biopsy of 11 people with Long COVID and PEM showed:

Microvascular abnormalities

Fewer capillaries

Increased macrophages

Gene signatures w/immune dysregulation and altered metabolic pathways.

Hypothesis: Initial viral infection caused immune-mediated structural changes of the microvasculature, potentially explaining the exercise-dependent fatigue and muscle pain.
https://buff.ly/3SliOd3

title: Fiction vs Reality: My Texts with Michael Shellenberger

last_post.content:
People say a lot of crazy things on the internet; I usually ignore it. But today, after nearly a full month of being smeared by Twitter Files writer Michael Shellenberger, including in sworn Congressional testimony, I’m releasing some files of my own: our WhatsApp texts, email conversation, and an interview that he did of me but never published.

I'm currently reading “Working backwards” about Amazon and I'm wondering how many people who quote the book actually read it. For example, yes, it describes the “two pizza teams”, but it also mentions that this was not a general success and was not applied globally over the company. Their conclusion was rather that not the size of the team was crucial, but the fact that it was autonomous and focused solely on a single objective. D’oh. https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/55297149

title: Case Study — Machine learning about sexual orientation?

last_post.content:
Michal Kosinksi just posted an arXiv paper claiming that "Theory of mind may have spontaneously emerged" in GPT3.

arxiv.org/abs/2302.02083

Why? He administered theory of mind instruments to the bot and it performed well.

Dr. Kosinksi has struggled before with how inference works; he thought the performance of his AI gaydar detector provided evidence for the prenatal hormone exposure hypothesis for sexual orientation rather than, say, self-presentation choices.

https://www.callingbullshit.org/case_studies/case_study_ml_sexual_orientation.html

title: 170  |  Formalizing Design with Gabrielle Mérite and Alan Wilson • Data Stories - via Podcast Addict

last_post.content:
I enjoyed the recent episode of #dataStories Formalizing Design with Gabrielle Mérite and Alan Wilson hosted by @moritz
https://podcastaddict.com/episode/154271571

It was fascinating to listen to their discussion on #designsystems , but what resonated most with me was the last part where Moritz stated how most #webdesign looks the same nowadays.

Of course that makes new websites easier to navigate, because they all have the same structure and style.

But it's also a bit boring.

What do you think?

New blog post with some reflections on using @deno_land for the past few months as my "default" non-browser Javascript runtime.

TLDR: I think it's excellent!

https://www.jeremiak.com/blog/a-few-months-of-deno-by-default/

I didn't realize how much I would appreciate #deno prioritizing web standards but fuck is it nice to have `fetch` and `import`.

Not to mention how that design pattern seeps into the community libraries that are developed, such as `deno_dom` which provides the browser DOM API for scraping.

title: Girl didn't want goat slaughtered; officials sent deputies

last_post.content:
RT @JMShumway
A young girl didn’t want to slaughter the goat she raised for 4H. The state senator who bought the goat at auction agreed to let it live out its days eating weeds. But sheriff’s deputies drove 500 miles to kill the goat and teach a 9-year-old a lesson.

Really excited to attend #JupyterCon in Paris next month!

Vincent Maladiere and I will give a full day tutorial on predictive Survival Analysis and Competing Risks modeling with a Gradient Boosting model assembled from generic scikit-learn building blocks. We will also introduce many concepts and model evaluation methodology using specialized libraries such as lifelines and scikit-survival.

Here is the full agenda for this session:

https://cfp.jupytercon.com/2023/talk/ACPULZ/
